title: 5 Easy Chicken Dinners Ready in 30 Minutes
promptIMG: Chicken dinners, on plate, natural food photography, balanced sharp focus, zero blur throughout entire image, infinite depth of field, realistic food textures, modern kitchen background in sharp focus, natural lighting, kitchen countertop visible, even focus distribution, documentary food photography, natural sharpness --no blur, depth of field, bokeh, over-sharpening, artificial enhancement --quality 2 --raw --stylize 300
description: Need dinner fast? These chicken recipes are super easy. 30 minutes, tastes great, nothing fancy. Just regular ingredients you probably have.
ingredients: 1 pound chicken breast, cut into strips
instructions: Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
Season chicken strips with garlic powder, paprika, salt, and pepper.
Add chicken to the skillet and cook for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until cooked through and golden brown.
tips: Make sure your pan is hot before you add the chicken. Don't put too much in at once.

structured_content.content: Sometimes you get home late and need food fast. This chicken thing works every time. Pretty simple, not weird, kids eat it. Takes about 30 minutes start to finish.
I make this maybe twice a month now. Started doing it when my work got busy and I stopped having time for complicated dinners. Turns out simple is better anyway.

note.label: Why This Works
note.content:
• Takes 30 minutes
  • Better than ordering pizza
  • Good for weeknights
  • Regular grocery store stuff
  • You can eat leftovers tomorrow

structured_content.content: First time I made this, my kids looked at it funny. But when it started cooking and the whole house smelled good, they came running. Now they actually ask for it. That never happens with vegetables or anything healthy.
The good thing about cooking chicken like this is you can change it around. Some nights I add more stuff, some nights just the chicken. Both ways taste fine. Depends on how tired I am really.
Not much stuff here. When you're cooking fast, you don't want to be looking for weird ingredients you bought once and never used again.

• Chicken breast: Just regular chicken from the store. Cut it into strips so it cooks faster. Try to make the pieces about the same size so they all get done at the same time.
  • Garlic powder and paprika: These two make it taste good. Not boring but not too spicy either. I always have both in my cabinet because I use them a lot.
  • Olive oil: Any olive oil works. The cheap kind is fine for cooking. Save the expensive bottle for salad or whatever.
  • Big pan: You need a big pan. If the chicken is all squished together it won't get brown and crispy. A 12 inch pan is what I use.

About the pan. I tried making this in a small pan once because my big one was dirty. Bad idea. Everything just steamed and got kind of gross instead of getting that nice brown color. Use a big pan, trust me.

upload.context: Preparation of chicken strips and seasoning.

structured_content.content: Pretty straightforward. There's a couple things that help though.

Get ready:
Cut up the chicken, put the garlic powder and paprika and salt and pepper on it. Use more than you think. I do this while the pan heats up. If the chicken is wet, dry it off with paper towels first. Wet chicken doesn't brown right.
Cook it:
Put oil in the pan, turn heat to medium. When the oil looks shiny and moves around easy, add the chicken. Don't mess with it for a few minutes. Just leave it alone so it gets brown. Then flip everything and cook a few more minutes. Should look golden brown, not white and sad.
You're done:
Put it on plates while it's hot. You can put some green stuff on top if you want but whatever.

Here's something. If some chicken pieces are way fatter than others, they won't cook at the same speed. I usually smack the fat parts with a pan or something heavy to make them flatter. Takes like 30 seconds and helps a lot.

upload.context: Cooking chicken strips in the skillet.

note.label: Don't Forget
note.content:
• Chicken needs to be 165 degrees inside. Get a thermometer.
  • Don't crowd the pan.
  • You want it golden brown.
  • Keeps in the fridge for 3 days.

structured_content.content: My neighbor came over last week without calling first. I just made this and had it ready in like 25 minutes. She thought I was some great cook and asked how I made it. I was like, there's barely even a recipe. It's just chicken with some stuff on it.

Leftovers are pretty good actually. Not like some chicken that gets all dry and weird the next day. I cut it up and put it in a salad for lunch sometimes. Or just eat it cold from the fridge. My husband does that. I think it's weird but he likes it.
It's good how it is but sometimes I want to do a little extra. Nothing crazy though. Maybe put some fresh parsley on top for color. Squeeze a lemon on it. Add hot pepper if you want it spicy.

One thing I started doing is making a quick sauce after the chicken is done. Just pour a little wine or chicken broth in the hot pan, scrape the brown bits off the bottom, let it cook down for a minute. Sounds fancy but it's really easy. Pour that over the chicken and people think you actually tried.
Also butter. If you throw a little chunk of butter in the pan at the very end, everything gets shiny and tastes richer. Literally takes 30 seconds and makes it seem like restaurant food.
Rice is easy. Salad. Any vegetables. Pasta if that's what you have. Whatever's in your fridge basically. I usually make rice in the rice cooker while I'm doing the chicken. Super easy combo.
Broccoli is good. Just put it in the oven with oil and salt while you cook the chicken. Or do a cucumber salad, that's fast. Just cut cucumbers, add vinegar and a tiny bit of sugar. Takes 5 minutes.

For bread or whatever, I do rice most of the time. Sometimes those little pasta things, couscous I think. They cook fast. Mashed potatoes if I feel like it but that's pretty rare on a Tuesday. Bread from the store is fine too.
You can use pork instead. Or shrimp, that cooks even faster. Maybe tofu if you don't eat meat. Just watch the time because they all cook at different speeds. Same spices work for everything though.

If you want to change the flavor, use different spices. Like instead of paprika, use cumin and put lime on it at the end. Now it tastes Mexican and you can put it in tacos. Or use Italian spices and eat it with pasta and red sauce. Same basic cooking, different taste.
Chicken thighs work too. They're cheaper usually when they're on sale. A little more fat so they stay juicy even if you mess up a bit. Cook time is about the same, maybe a minute longer.

upload.context: Final plated chicken dinner with sides.

note.label: Extra Stuff
note.content:
• Let chicken sit for 2 minutes after cooking.
  • You can marinate it first if you have time but you don't have to.
  • Thermometer helps you not screw it up.
  • Try to make it look nice on the plate.

structured_content.content: If you know you're gonna have a crazy week, you can season the chicken ahead of time and keep it in the fridge. Then just cook it when you get home. I do this on Sundays sometimes. Put seasoned chicken in plastic bags, 3 or 4 bags. Makes the week way easier.

Actually I even made a big jar of the spice mixture. Just mixed up a bunch of garlic powder and paprika and keep it in a jar. Now I just shake it on the chicken and don't have to think about it. Saves time when you're tired from work and your brain isn't working right.
Try it next time you need dinner fast. Works every time. Way better than getting takeout. Cheaper too. I've made this so many times now I don't even think about it anymore. Just automatic.

Once you make it a few times and get comfortable, you can start messing around with it. Add different stuff, try new spices, whatever. That's when cooking stops being annoying and starts being kind of fun. Even on a weeknight when you're exhausted and just want to sit down.
